Layouts & Positioning

Advanced Grids

Looking for a refresher on the basics of Gridlex? Read this article in the pre-coursework. 

Nested Grids

Using Gridlex you can nest grids inside grids – the important thing to remember is that the parent element always has a class of grid and the child elements always have a class of col-*. 

In this example, we have a section with a heading and subheading and then 4 content blocks each with an image and text. The grid structure would look something like this. 

<section class="grid">
  <!-- Column for Heading -->
  <div class="col-12"> ... </div>​​​​​​

  <!-- First grey column -->
  ​<div class="col-6 grid grey">
    <div class="col-6 orange"> ...  </div>
    <div class="col-6 text">  ... </div>
  </div>

  <!-- Second grey column -->
  <div class="col-6 grid grey">
    <div class="col-6 orange"> ...  </div>
    <div class="col-6 text">  ... </div>
  </div>

  <!-- Third grey column -->
  <div class="col-6 grid grey">
    <div class="col-6 orange"> ...  </div>
    <div class="col-6 text">  ... </div>
  </div>

  <!-- Last grey column -->
  <div class="col-6 grid grey">
    <div class="col-6 orange"> ...  </div>
    <div class="col-6 text">  ... </div>
  </div>
</section>

We need to make sure that we wrap the heading and sub-heading in a col-12 even though it’s taking up the full width because every child of a grid must be a column itself. 

While that can feel overwhelming, the easiest way of thinking about is it…
- is this element the direct child of a grid? Then it needs a col- class.
- is this element a direct parent of a column? Then in needs a grid class. 

Grid Options 

Vertical Alignment 

You can vertically align the contents of your grid by adding ‘-middle’ ‘-bottom’ or ‘top’ to your grid. 

<div class="grid-middle">
  <div class="col-6"> ... </div>
  <div class="col-6"> ... </div>
</div>

Horizontal Distribution

If your total columns add to less than 12 you will have space left over. You can decide what to do with this space in three ways. 

-spaceBetween equally divides the space to fill the gaps between each element 

-spaceAround equally divides the space to wrap around each element (inlcluding the left and right edge).

-center pushes the columns to the center and leaves the space on either side. 

<div class="grid-spaceBetween">
  <div class="col-6"> ... </div>
  <div class="col-6"> ... </div>
</div>

Make sure you pay attention to the capitalisation (spaceBetween not SpaceBetween) as it does make a difference.
